'''Coot Grant''' (June 17, 1893 – unknown)<ref name="Alabama">{{cite web |url=http://www.alabamamusicoffice.com/artists-a-z/g/895-grant-leola-coot |title=Leola Coot Grant |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Alabamamusicoffice.com |accessdate=October 10, 2011}}</ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[classic female blues]], [[country blues]], and [[vaudeville]], singer and songwriter.<ref name="AMG"/> Her own stage craft, plus the double act with her husband and musical partner, Wesley "Kid" Wilson, was popular with [[African American]] audiences in the 1910s, 1920s and early 1930s.<ref name="Review">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r332842/review|pure_url=yes}} |title=Allmusic ((( ''Complete Recorded Works, Vol. 1 (1925-1928)'' > Review )))}}</ref><ref>{{cite book
| first= Sammy 
| last= Price
| year= 1989
| title= What do they want?: a jazz autobiography
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Bayou Press Limited 
| location= Wheatley, Oxford, England
| isbn= 1-871478-25-1
| page= 32}}</ref>

==Biography==
One of fifteen offspring, she was born '''Leola B. Pettigrew''' in [[Birmingham, Alabama]], [[United States]].<ref name="Review"/> The first part of her eventual [[stage name]] came from a derivation of her childhood [[nickname]], 'Cutie'. She began work in 1900 in [[Atlanta, Georgia]], appearing in vaudeville, and the following year toured [[South Africa]] and across Europe with Mayme Remington's Pickaninnies. She was sometimes billed as Patsy Hunter. In 1913, she married the singer, Isiah I. Grant, and they worked on stage together before his death in 1920.  She married [[Wesley Wilson]] the same year,<ref name="Review"/> but he surpassed her on stage names being later variously billed as Catjuice Charlie (in a brief duo with Pigmeat Pete), Kid Wilson, Jenkins, Socks, and Sox Wilson. He played both piano and organ, whilst Coot Grant strummed guitar as well as sing and dance.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p289584|pure_url=yes}}|title=Coot Grant|author=Eugene Chadbourne |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=October 10, 2011}}</ref>  

The duo's billing also varied between Grant and Wilson, Kid and Coot, and Hunter and Jenkins, as they went on to appear and later record with [[Fletcher Henderson]], [[Mezz Mezzrow]], [[Sidney Bechet]], and [[Louis Armstrong]]. Their variety was such that they performed separately and together in vaudeville, musical comedies, revues and traveling shows. This ability to adapt also saw them appear in the 1933 [[film]], ''[[The Emperor Jones (1933 film)|The Emperor Jones]]'', alongside [[Paul Robeson]].<ref name="AMG"/>

In addition to this, the twosome wrote in excess of 400 songs over their working lifetime.<ref name="Fuqua">{{cite book
| first= C.S.
| last= Fuqua
| year= 2011
| title= Alabama Musicians: Musical Heritage from the Heart of Dixie
| edition= 1st
| publisher= The History Press 
| location= Charleston, South Carolina
| isbn= 978-1-60949-157-4
| page= 151}}</ref>  That list included "Gimme a Pigfoot (And a Bottle of Beer)" ([[1933 in music|1933]]) and "Take Me for a Buggy Ride", which were both made famous by [[Bessie Smith]]'s recording of the songs, plus "Find Me at the Greasy Spoon" and "Prince of Wails" for Fletcher Henderson. Their own renditions included the diverse, "Come on Coot, Do That Thing" (1925), "Dem Socks Dat My Pappy Wore," and "Throat Cutting Blues" (although the latter remains unreleased)."<ref name="AMG"/>

In 1926, Grant joined up with [[Blind Blake]], and recorded a selection of [[country blues]] renditions.<ref name="AMG"/> These were Blake's debut recordings.<ref name="Review"/> Although Grant and Wilson's act, once seen as a serious rival to [[Butterbeans and Susie]],<ref name="Review"/> began to lose favor with the public by the middle of the 1930s, they recorded further songs in 1938.<ref name="AMG"/>  Their only child, Bobby Wilson, was born in 1941.<ref name="Review 2">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r332844/review|pure_url=yes}} |title=Allmusic ((( ''Complete Recorded Works, Vol. 3 (1931-1938)'' > Review )))}}</ref>  By 1946, and after [[Mezz Mezzrow]] had founded his King Jazz [[record label]], he engaged them as songwriters.<ref name="AMG"/> In that year, the association led to their final recording session backed by a quintet incorporating Bechet and Mezzrow.<ref name="Review 2"/>

Wilson retired in ill health shortly thereafter,<ref name="Fuqua"/> but Grant continued performing into the 1950s.<ref name="AMG"/> In January 1953, one commentator noted that the couple had moved from [[New York City|New York]] to [[Los Angeles]], but were in considerable financial hardship.<ref>{{cite book
| first= Floyd
| last= Levin
| year= 2000
| title= Classic Jazz: A Personal View of the Music and the Musicians
| edition= 1st
| publisher= University of California Press 
| location= Los Angeles, California
| isbn= 0-520-23463-4
| pages= 169/172}}</ref>  Grant's popularity waned to such an extent that no official details have been uncovered concerning her death.<ref name="AMG"/>

Her entire recorded work, both with and without Wilson, was made available in three chronological volumes in 1998 by [[Document Records]].<ref name="Albums"/>
